events.text: Tonight's the night.
You have all the provisions you need to survive the trip.
It’s the perfect opportunity to get out before Father finds you.
The rain and wind will cover your tracks and sounds.
The house feels too silent tonight.
Distantly, Father calls for you.
My son, where are you?

You take a measured breath. As much as you loved your father, you knew staying here wasn’t going to help. 
You can never mold yourself to his expectations–you simply can’t change who you are.
You set the letter you had written for him on your desk. No matter how many times you had told him that you couldn’t change, he kept insisting, kept trying to “fix” you.
Hopefully after you’re gone, he will understand.
I want to help you, [YOUR NAME]. You don’t have to be like this anymore.
Years ago, Father had helped Roger–one of the young men in your church–by sending him away. The church thanked God for “saving” him from the Devil.
But Roger returned as a shell of himself, shaken and pale. He doesn’t talk to anyone nowadays. Not even with his wife.
The train will leave for the West tomorrow morning, to bring you as far away from New York as possible. You check your pocket change–it’s just enough.
The train will leave for the West tomorrow morning, to bring you as far away from Oklahoma as possible. You check your pocket change–it’s just enough.
As long as you get away from your hometown where Father is the head pastor–without him or anyone in the community noticing and dragging you to [i]purification[/i]–you’ll be safe.
You check your pocket change–it’s just enough to compensate those who would be willing to let you ride in their car.
You hear Father mutter a prayer under his breath.
Dear Lord, save my son. Help him see the truth. Give him the courage to receive help. Amen.
Father sighs.

events.question: I just want to talk. The Devil has somehow influenced you, and I want to help you get better. Don’t you want to be sinless in the eyes of God?

events.text: Yes, Father? What will we talk about?
There are programs that will cure you of homosexuality. I want to discuss some of them with you.
No, Father. I don’t need to be “cured.”

Remember Leviticus, my son: “Thou shalt not lie with mankind, as with womankind: it is abomination.”
I do not want you to be condemned to hellfire, [YOUR NAME]. You must change if you want to enter Heaven. 
Please, my son, I just want to help you. Come out and talk to me.

You hush yourself.
Just like before, no amount of words were going to convince him otherwise.
You hush yourself.
Son?
He sighs.
Please, my son, I just want to help you. Come out and talk to me.

events.question: You have to decide your next move, quickly.

events.text: You take it slowly, avoiding the steps you know to be creaky.
Eventually, you make it to the main hall. The front door is within reach.
Behind you–
There you are, [YOUR NAME]. Don’t be afraid.
Father takes a slow step forward.
I just want to help you, my son.
You run to the door and throw it open, out into the pouring rain and mud.
[YOUR NAME]!
You slide the window open a little wider, cringing when it makes a sharp squeak.
[YOUR NAME]?
You hear heavy boots creak against the stairs leading to your room.
Frantically, you throw the rope over and slide down, the coarse thick rope burning your hands.
Suddenly, from above you-
There you are, [YOUR NAME]. Please, be careful! Don’t hurt yourself!
The rope’s too short. You jump the rest of the way down, praying to whatever god exists that you don’t break your legs.
It [i]hurts[/i], but you barely feel it due to the pure [i]panic[/i].
[YOUR NAME]!
You squeeze yourself under the bed and pull boxes to cover yourself.
Father’s footsteps make the floorboards creak.
The door slowly opens and Father enters.
I’ll save you from the Devil’s grasp, my son. God will save you. Please, I only want to help you, [YOUR NAME].
You hear his steps shuffle around the room, then the assuring sound of the door opening and closing again.
You count to ten and hurry out from your hiding place, opening the door and running down the stairs, to the front door, to [i]freedom[/i]–
Suddenly, from behind you-
There you are, [YOUR NAME].
You run to the door and throw it open, out into the pouring rain and mud.
[YOUR NAME]!
In record time, you hear the front door slam open, and you know Father is running after you.
I’m not going to hurt you, [YOUR NAME]! Please, come back!
Adrenaline rushes through your veins, and you force yourself to run and [i]keep running or else he’ll catch you, force you to be "cured"–[/i]
Suddenly, there’s a loud roar of lightning that almost blows your eardrums off. You feel heat behind you.
Aargh!!
You spin around and see a car parked on the side of the road is on fire, the flames quickly spreading.
You spin around and see the grass between you and Father is on fire, the flames quickly spreading.
You spin around and see one of the houses is on fire, the flames quickly spreading.
Father is covering his eyes, as if he can’t see.
The lightning had blinded him.
You keep running until you reach the train, mud and rain in your shoes, your backpack and provisions absolutely soaked–
At the train station, you curl up on a bench. You can’t stop trembling. Is this happiness? Is this relief? Adrenaline? Fear?
You keep running until you reach the train, mud and rain in your shoes, your backpack and provisions absolutely soaked–
At the train station, you curl up on a bench. You can’t stop trembling. Is this happiness? Is this relief? Adrenaline? Fear?
You keep running until you reach the gas station, mud and rain in your shoes, your backpack and provisions absolutely soaked–
Under the roof of a gas station, you curl up on a bench. You can’t stop trembling. Is this happiness? Is this relief? Adrenaline? Fear?
It’s the middle of the night, still. What if Father finds you?
You can’t stop shaking. It’s cold. The sky flashes with lightning. Thunder and rain roars around you.

Father is kind and has taken care of you all your life, but when it came to his beliefs… he was uncompromising. You will miss him, but running away was necessary for your sanity.
As you look up at the cloudy sky, you wonder how your life will play out from here on, now that you are truly alone.
Your cheeks feel wet, and it’s not just from the rain.
[i]Meow.[/i]
It sounds close. Is that… the sound of a kitten?

events.question: There’s a small, soaked box slowly making its way out into the rain, a tiny black tail peeking out from the box’s opening.

events.text: You walk over and gently pick up the small box.
Once the box reaches the rain, it releases another meow and turns around, slowly making its way towards you. It walks into the leg of your bench.
You glance at it curiously.
Once the box reaches the rain, it releases another meow and turns around, slowly making its way towards you. It walks into the leg of your bench.
You glance at it curiously.
A small black kitten peers at you and releases a long meow.
You pick it up.
It reaches its paws towards you. You gently cradle it in your hands and notice one of its legs, no more than a stump, is bleeding.
Oh no, you’re hurt. I'll help.
You gently treat the kitten’s wound as best as you can with what little provisions you have.
Who in their right mind would cut off a kitten’s limb? Or was it an accident?
Once you finish, the kitten rubs its head against your hand and curls into your palm, basking in your warmth.
You smile.
I think I’ll name you Soot.
The next day, you and Soot board the train West.
The next day, you and Soot board the train West.
The next day, you and Soot begin your journey away from home.
